data.title: I can't open files outside of project root in my existing editor
data.body:
If I'm working in github/gist, and attempt to open just the Gemfile from github/github, it opens the full github/github project in a separate editor.  

Halp tickets:
- support/ba2dac0aadb511e395a7ae0ef24939f7

data.title: A smarter undo
data.body:
Numerous users mentioned this as pain (including myself) -- currently, undo (cmd-z) is operating at a one-character-at-a-time level. However, users expect a smarter undo, like in Chrome, where whole words or parts of sentences are undone. 

I'm wondering if this is intentional so that an external package could provide this "smarter" undo, or is this something that we might consider improving in Atom core?

http://discuss.atom.io/t/system-undo-functionality-vs-atom-undo-redo-functionality/806
support/097824ae9f9f11e383096d36ce2a1193
support/a6d237229fd011e38e277c6d2e351775
support/e8bde9c8a07611e38dee98364966fbc6
support/a7ef7a1ca16e11e3992e88197be71476

data.title: Apply 'scrollbars-visible-always/when-scrolling' class to WorkspaceView
data.body:
As is discussed in #1672, styling scrollbars forces them to be visible. We want to be able to _only_ style scrollbars if the user's has chosen to have them always be visible to begin with, and otherwise leave the overlay behavior.

This PR adds a `scrollbars-visible-always` or `scrollbars-visible-when-scrolling` class to the workspace view so we can only enable scrollbar styles when scrollbars are visible "always". This should help us merge PRs like atom/atom-dark-ui#12.

data.title: JavaScript users are having trouble subclassing View
data.body: See [this forum post](http://discuss.atom.io/t/coffeescript---extends-vs-util-inherits-inheritance-in-js)

data.title: Styling scrollbars forces them to always be visible
data.body:
...but not styling causes them to be ugly when the always visible option is enabled.

I'm thinking we need to detect whether or not scrollbars are always enabled and add a class to the workspace to indicate it.

data.title: Improve Workspace and WorkspaceView API docs
data.body:
This just cleans up all the public method docs on these two classes and improves their overview.

One potentially controversial change was the removal of the command summary from `WorkspaceView`, since I think people should call methods rather than triggering commands programmatically.

I've also started exporting `Workspace` from the `atom` module so people can construct only a model in specs.

data.title: Cmd-a shortcut to select all doesn't work in Save As dialog
data.body:
Reported here:
- support/5401cd6e9fe411e39aecbd941b627890

> Cmd-A doesn’t work in the text field inside a native save panel.

![screen shot 2014-03-03 at 10 44 34 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/2314945/6114e5fe-a31d-11e3-81ee-b0825213bd7e.png)

data.title: ctrl-cmd-down combo for switching lines produces a sound
data.body:
Reported by a few users:
- http://discuss.atom.io/t/audible-bell-sounds-when-moving-text-down/2089
- support/fc6c2ac6a04d11e38e5adef6c2d169fb
- support/25cfbdeca0ad11e389626d489492fcbc
- support/b537abfea0b011e3946f5df3635c9d01

> If you highlight text in Atom and then press CTRL+CMD+DOWN ARROW, the text will move, but you'll get an audible warning bell. This doesn't happen when moving text upwards.

Did a bit of digging, and it seems that [Brackets has the same problem](https://github.com/adobe/brackets/issues/2419).

data.title: Featured package listing bleeds out of the view strangely.
data.body:
It looks like there is a fixed width on the featured packages container, so on an even moderately sized window you have to horizontally scroll the list. Since they're modular, it makes sense to wrap them rather than enforce a count per line.

![screen shot 2014-03-03 at 12 17 43 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/72919/2314051/fed62418-a310-11e3-99d7-47c7166b5ccb.png)

data.title: Long line breaks syntax highlighting
data.body:
I opened a Python file with the following line (#963):

``` python
                    PrintAndLog(u"SSID: " + RememberedNetwork["SSIDString"].decode("utf-8") + u" - BSSID: " + RememberedNetwork["CachedScanRecord"]["BSSID"] + u" - RSSI: " + str(RememberedNetwork["CachedScanRecord"]["RSSI"]) + u" - Last connected: " + str(RememberedNetwork["LastConnected"]) + u" - Security type: " +  RememberedNetwork["SecurityType"] + u" - Geolocation: " + Geolocation, "INFO")
```

Which led to the following bug:
![screen shot 2014-03-03 at 2 52 40 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/2313778/76bb4bba-a30d-11e3-9a64-81f6f91c25c4.png)

You can find this as the main file in [`osxauditor.py`](https://github.com/jipegit/OSXAuditor/blob/master/osxauditor.py).

data.title: Scrolling quality
data.body:
I think scrolling was the number 1 issue in the number of tickets we received in Halp. Users reported it was strange, unnatural, too fast, janky, not like any other app, etc.

A few specific things:
- scrolling on retina seems to be worse
- scrolling horizontally (soft wrap is off) when the file has a bunch of long lines is janky -- instead of a smooth horizontal scroll, you get a mixed horizontal-vertical scroll. I observed this as well.

Here's a bunch of forum discussions and Halp tickets:
- http://discuss.atom.io/t/scroll-performance-behavior/291
- support/c794ff649fce11e38f689a15fc3ef34a
- support/2f46d7f49f5711e3890418da83a15e5b
- support/bc04b8589f7711e395a962430ae6bf38

data.title: Using quotes with multiple selections
data.body:
When there are multiple selections, pressing `"` doesn't wrap the selection. It replaces all selections with a single `"`.

/via support/e43db338a09911e3978c0910ce06379d?page=1

data.title: Handling user feedback
data.body:
The Beta launch of Atom was a huge success! :zap: :globe_with_meridians: :zap: 

We received tons of positive feedback and :heart:, and getting back to users and answering questions was an amazing experience. Still, we can do better in helping users give us feedback so that [we don't get overloaded](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1621). It will be easier on us, and a better experience for them. 

The majority of tickets we received from Atom's in-app Feedback form were bug reports and feature requests for specific packages. We created a few canned responses to handle those types of questions, but that mostly creates unnecessary load on us and an interaction delay for users.

As @bnferguson said, the [Feedback form](https://github.com/atom/feedback) is the key piece of solving this -- it should instruct users where to submit which type of feedback.

![](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/671378/2241417/636173a2-9cd0-11e3-8e3e-f16f98820c40.png)

Here's a few ideas for things we might include in the feedback form:
- Tell users that most parts of Atom are packages which are open source repositories (a lot of users don't know this). We give a few example (e.g. tree view, tabs, command palette), and link those examples to their repositories. Also, we give links to the [atom.io package list](https://atom.io/packages) where it's possible to search packages and the in-app package list where they can click on the "Report issue" button.
- Tell users that they can submit bug reports and feature requests for packages by creating issues on the associated repositories.
- Tell users that they can submit ideas for new packages and general feedback on [the forums](http://discuss.atom.io/) (Why will we charge for atom? Where's the windows version? Anyone making a package for real-time collaboration?)
- Link to [the FAQ](https://atom.io/faq) ("Make sure you check out the FAQ")
- Link to [the contributing docs](https://atom.io/docs/v0.64.0/contributing) so that they know how to submit feedback ("Check out our contributing guide for tips on providing feedback and making pull requests")

From experience, users reacted really well to our responses so far, which were based on the guidelines above. We have awesome users :heart:, let's provide an even more amazing support experience!

I'd also love to hear everyone's thoughts about the forums (I'm not active there yet). Are people getting along there? What's working okay, and what's not? Anything we can do to make the experience better?

cc @probablycorey @nathansobo @kevinsawicki @thedaniel @cameronmcefee @bnferguson @jonmagic @gjtorikian @sundaykofax @mojombo

data.title: Update available message is worded oddly
data.body:
Just noticed this:

![2014-03-03 at 12 10 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/2309173/0498d146-a2cd-11e3-82c2-5c89dab7f711.png)

An update "is being downloading" isn’t correct. It should either be "is being downloaded" or "is downloading".

data.title: Public API for vScrollMargin
data.body:
This was originally brought up as a part of atom/vim-mode#77, currently the amount of vertical scroll padding isn't configurable and it isn't queryable by extensions. It would atleast be nice if plugins that were interested in this could access the value.

Ref:
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/editor-view.coffee#L63

What are everyone's thoughts here?

data.title: Upgrade to atom-shell@0.10.4
data.body:
- Fix unresponsive window when using alert().
- Suppress CFAllocator warning, fixes #1627.
- Fix a crash from node.

data.title: Dvorak - Qwerty ⌘ support
data.body:
I've been typing in Dvorak for a long time and have come to rely on the Dvorak - Qwerty ⌘ keyboard layout on OS X. This layout is nice because it not only allows me to type in Dvorak, but it also allows me to use Qwerty keyboard shortcuts while holding down the ⌘ key. Unfortunately, the latter does not work as expected in Atom.

Would you consider adding support for this?

/cc @benburkert

data.title: Add screenRangeForTokenElement?
data.body:
http://github.com/madebysource/atom-color-highlighting

He's trying to hide the color highlighting when the selection hits one of the highlighted objects. A little info about this project:
- he's searching for all the `.numeric.css` and similar nodes on each `editor:display-updated` event
- he is setting background color on each one of these elements
- he wants to unhighlight them when the selection hits them
- the idea is for each node to check if in a selection, then render/not (could be slow??)

This might be better served with marker views. Then we could just z-index them lower than the selection. They might not be fast enough, though.

data.title: Allow multiple unsaved buffers
data.body:
If `open` is called with no uri, we should always open a new unsaved buffer.

Refs #1600

data.title: Something wrong with the node distro?
data.body:
From https://github.com/atom/emmet/issues/32#issuecomment-36432112:

```
gyp info it worked if it ends with ok
gyp info using node-gyp@0.10.10
gyp info using node@0.10.5 | darwin | x64
gyp http GET https://gh-contractor-zcbenz.s3.amazonaws.com/atom-shell/dist/v0.11.10/node-v0.11.10.tar.gz
gyp http 200 https://gh-contractor-zcbenz.s3.amazonaws.com/atom-shell/dist/v0.11.10/node-v0.11.10.tar.gz
gyp ERR! UNCAUGHT EXCEPTION
gyp ERR! stack Error: EPERM, utime '/Users/M8M/.atom/.node-gyp/.node-gyp/0.11.10'
gyp ERR! System Darwin 13.0.0
gyp ERR! command "/opt/boxen/nodenv/versions/v0.10.5/bin/node" "/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/node-gyp/bin/node-gyp.js" "install" "--target=0.11.10" "--dist-url=https://gh-contractor-zcbenz.s3.amazonaws.com/atom-shell/dist" "--arch=x64"
gyp ERR! cwd /Users/M8M/.atom
gyp ERR! node -v v0.10.5
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v0.10.10
gyp ERR! This is a bug in `node-gyp`.
gyp ERR! Try to update node-gyp and file an Issue if it does not help:
gyp ERR!     <https://github.com/TooTallNate/node-gyp/issues>
```

> This error also happens for me for most other @atom plugins

data.title: Restore state after restart (and/or reboot of the machine?)
data.body:
Something like Chrome does would be ideal, but I'm not super picky. Also, this is pretty low priority for me so consider this issue me planting a seed for a future date where you'll have the time to work on it ;)

The title is a bit misleading given what I _actually_ would love to have - But very specifically, upon reboot (in OSX at the very least) it would be _amazing_ to have Atom remember which directories/projects and which files I had open scrolled to whatever position I left them.

If I remember correctly, I'm pretty sure we already keep track of and possibly even already serialize this state, somewhere. If so, I'd love to be able to reboot my machine and have Atom reopen right where I left off.

data.title: Invert I-bar cursor when a dark theme is used
data.body:
The I-bar cursor is currently always black in Atom.  This makes it very hard to track when using a theme with a dark background.  Sublime inverts this cursor when you're using a dark theme... and it's quite wonderful.  I'd love if Atom did this too.

I don't think you can take a screenshot of the cursor, so here's some crazy photos.  Top is Atom, bottom is Sublime.  Both are using a dark solarized theme.

![2014-02-28 21 30 32](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/706/2300567/95771684-a0fa-11e3-8351-881401e7a672.jpg)

data.title: Multi-keystrokes cannot be overridden
data.body:
For example, if you make `cmd-k` to a command in your keymap.cson, it won't work because `cmd-k` is used in a multi-keystroke binding.

I think the expected behavior should be a single keystroke overrides multi-keystroke bindings.

/via support/a71114f29fac11e39b058ef835918707?page=1

data.title: Font rendering looks poor on non-retina
data.body:
> Font rendering looks non-native. In particular, on non-retina displays with subpixel font rendering enabled, it looks like your fonts are using a different rendering engine (Freetype?) and at least are not using subpixel antialiasing. It looks janky. I suppose you don't notice on a retina display?

From: support/6d8865b29fb811e391bb3f51061e064b

data.title: Deleting hidden folder causes Atom to freeze
data.body: When Trying to delete a hidden folder, Atom Freezes, and the folder isn't deleted. Afterwards, Atom Helper is present in the background, taking up lots of CPU time.

I forget what this is used for. I'm sure there is reason for it, but I don't think it needs to be exposed in production.

data.title: Detect and resolve file paths in files
data.body:
/img mind blown

support/c1480c969fbf11e39822f9a01bbb8911?page=1

It'd be awesome if we could detect files, and provide a way to navigate to the link (relative or absolute). Perhaps it becomes a context menu option when you right click on a file path.
